page.title: 01Review of the block, Faceby
page.content: This covers most of{Whorlton,}all of {Faceby}parish and parts of{Potto,} {Carlton}and{Swainby.}Except for part of the NW corner, it is in the{North} {York Moors National Park,}and is flat agricultural land rising from 260 ft to an exposed N-facing escarpment 1338 ft high. There are no shops, markets, businesses, schools, almost no industries except agriculture, and no major roads. Faceby, a commuter village 14 miles from Teesside, has many residents working there in industry, the professions and commerce. Whorlton, divided from Faceby by Whorl Hill, a natural landmark, has a ruined Norman castle and church, and few houses. Swainby includes only the area round Mill Farm, with part of the now disused railway laid in 1857 to carry calcined ironstone from Scugdale mines.
